message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient has gallstones, and the molecule responsible for increasing pain after eating fatty foods is cholecystokinin (CCK), which is secreted by I cells in the duodenum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest the patient has cholecystitis, an inflammation of the gallbladder. The pain after eating fatty foods is due to increased secretion of cholecystokinin (CCK) by I cells in the small intestine. CCK stimulates the gallbladder to contract and release bile into the small intestine to aid in digestion of fats.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient may have gallbladder disease, specifically cholecystitis. The increased pain after eating fatty foods is caused by the release of cholecystokinin (CCK), which is secreted by I cells in the small intestine. CCK causes the gallbladder to contract and release bile, which can exacerbate symptoms in patients with gallbladder disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest the most likely diagnosis is cholecystitis or gallstones. I cells secrete cholecystokinin (CCK), which is responsible for the contraction of the gallbladder and the release of digestive enzymes from the pancreas, causing increased pain after eating fatty foods.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest cholecystitis, and the increased pain after eating fatty foods suggests a role of the hormone cholecystokinin (CCK) which is secreted by I cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of abdominal pain, worsened by fatty food, and nausea suggest cholecystitis. The molecule responsible for increased pain after eating fatty foods is cholecystokinin, which is secreted by I cells in the duodenum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient's symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is cholecystitis or gallbladder disease. The molecule responsible for increased pain after eating fatty foods is likely to be cholecystokinin (CCK), which is secreted by I cells in the duodenum. CCK causes the gallbladder to contract and release bile to aid in fat digestion, which can exacerbate the pain in patients with gallbladder disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This patient’s symptoms suggest pancreatitis, which can be exacerbated by fatty foods. Secretin, which is produced by I cells in the duodenum, causes the release of pancreatic enzymes and bicarbonate and can worsen pancreatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest gallbladder disease, which is often associated with increased pain after eating fatty foods. The hormone responsible for stimulating gallbladder contraction in response to fatty foods is cholecystokinin (CCK), which is secreted mainly by I cells in the duodenum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest gallbladder disease, specifically cholecystitis, which is often exacerbated by fatty foods. The I cells in the duodenum secrete cholecystokinin (CCK), which stimulates the contraction of the gallbladder and the release of bile to aid in fat digestion. Therefore, the increased pain after eating fatty foods is likely due to the increased secretion of CCK.
